description.plain:
Symere Bysil Woods (b. July 31, 1994), popularly known as Lil Uzi Vert, is an American recording artist from Philadelphia, Pennsylvania.

In an interview with Vibe Magazine, the Francisville, North Philadelphia native explained the origins of his stage name:

Some guy was just like ‘You rap fast, man. Like a little machine gun,’ and from that moment I was Lil Uzi.

Uzi also added “Vert” to the end of his stage name. In an interview with Rolling Stone, Uzi described the meaning of “Vert” as “straight to the top, like a vertical leap.“ Lil Uzi Vert is also a loose homophone for Lucifer, a name that fits perfectly with his satanic image.

Uzi first gained recognition with the release of single “Money Longer” and his 2015 mixtape Luv Is Rage. However, Uzi’s feature on Migos' “Bad and Boujee” and the release of his hit single “XO TOUR Llif3” gave Uzi significant popularity and exposure, peaking at #1 and #7 on the Billboard Hot 100 respectively.

Lil Uzi Vert’s style has been compared to Lil Wayne on multiple occasions, and his style has been described as emo rap with some elements of rock. He has also been called a lo-fi rapper. Uzi calls Marilyn Manson one of his biggest inspirations.

On August 25, 2017, Uzi released his highly-anticipated debut studio album, Luv Is Rage 2, a sequel to his first mixtape. The album debuted at #1 and is certified platinum.

On January 11, 2019, Uzi allegedly quit music and claimed he would be deleting all of his music on an Instagram story:

I wanna take the time out to say I think each and every one of my [supporters] but I’m done with music I deleted everything I wanna be normal. I wanna wake up in 2013

On March 25, 2019, Complex confirmed that Lil Uzi Vert was being managed by Roc Nation, even amidst long-term conflicts with Uzi’s label, Generation Now, and he returned to music with the single “Free Uzi” three days later.

On March 6, 2020, after over a two-year delay and releasing a majority of singles in 2019, the rapper dropped his highly-anticipated second studio album, Eternal Atake. It features his highest-charting Billboard Hot 100 single, “Futsal Shuffle 2020” and “That Way” with classic pinch of Backstreet Boys' 1999 smash hit, “I Want It That Way”.

Only a week later on March 13th, 2020, Uzi released the deluxe version of Eternal Atake titled “Eternal Atake (Deluxe) – LUV vs. The World 2” which also serves as the sequel to his 2016 mixtape Lil Uzi Vert vs The World. It features many highly anticipated songs such as “Lotus”, “Bean (Kobe)”, and more. Other artists, such as 21 Savage and Young Thug also make appearances.

description.plain:
“XO Tour Llif3” is a chronicle of Uzi’s relationship issues with ex-girlfriend, Brittany Byrd, and substance abuse. It’s delivered over bassy and upbeat production but addresses topics like suicide and betrayal.  Ultimately, it’s a narrative mixed with strong emotional dialogue, outlining a big fight between him and his girlfriend.

LUV premiered the track in London while opening for The Weeknd’s Starboy: Legend of the Fall 2017 world tour, following the song’s leak. The title pays homage to The Weeknd’s label XO, in light of the performance.

https://www.instagram.com/p/BRVujQLAHO5/?taken-by=liluzivert

Eternal Atake’s “P2” is continuation of XO Tour Llif3. Uzi raps about moving on from heartbreak and continuing his career, problem-free. P2 is the outro to Eternal Atake, excluding two bonus tracks.

songs.lyrics:
[Intro]
Are you alright?
I'm alright, I'm quite alright
And my money's right
8… (Yeah)
Countin' them bands
All way to the top 'til they be fallin' over
(Yeah, yeah, yeah)
Countin' them bands
On my way to the top 'til we fallin' over

[Chorus]
I don't really care if you cry
On the real, you shoulda never lied
Shoulda saw the way she looked me in my eyes
She said, "Baby, I am not afraid to die"
Push me to the edge
All my friends are dead
Push me to the edge
All my friends are dead
Push me to the edge
All my friends are dead
Push me to the edge

[Verse 1]
Phantom that's all red, inside all white
Like somethin' you ride a sled down, I just want that head
My Brittany got mad, I'm barely her man now
Everybody got the same swag now
Watch the way that I tear it down
Stackin' my bands all the way to the top
All the way 'til my bands fallin' over
Every time that you leave your spot
Your girlfriend call me like, "Come on over!"
I like the way that she treat me
Gon' leave you, won't leave me, I call it that Casanova
She say I'm insane, yeah
I might blow my brain out (Hey)
Xanny, help the pain, yeah
Please, Xanny, make it go away
I'm committed, not addicted, but it keep control of me
All the pain, now I can't feel it
I swear that it's slowin' me, yeah

[Chorus]
I don't really care if you cry
On the real, you shoulda never lied
Saw the way she looked me in my eyes
She said, "I am not afraid to die" (Yeah)
All my friends are dead
Push me to the edge (Yeah)
All my friends are dead, yeah, ooh
Push me to the edge
All my friends are dead, yeah
All my friends are dead, yeah

[Verse 2]
That is not your swag, I swear you fake hard
Now these niggas wanna take my cadence
Rain on 'em, thunderstorm, rain on 'em (Ooh, yeah)
Medicine, lil' nigga, take some (Yeh, yeh)
Fast car, NASCAR, race on 'em
In the club, ain't got no ones, then we would beg them
Clothes from overseas, got the racks and they all C-Notes
You is not a G though
Lookin' at you stackin' all your money, it all green though
I was countin' that and these all twenties, that's a G-roll

[Bridge]
She say, "You're the worst, you're the worst"
I cannot die because this my universe

[Chorus]
I don't really care if you cry
On the real, you shoulda never lied
Shoulda saw the way she looked me in my eyes
She said, "Baby, I am not afraid to die"
Push me to the edge
All my friends are dead
Push me to the edge
All my friends are dead
Push me to the edge
All my friends are dead
Push me to the edge

description.plain: In keeping with the theme of the majority of songs on the project, Uzi is presumably singing about his ex-girlfriend Brittany Byrd. Taking a melodic approach, Uzi trades his metaphor filled bars for a harmonic interpolation of Oh Wonder’s “Landslide”on the chorus. He reassures himself that despite his heartbreak, time is the ultimate healer.

songs.full_title: New Patek by Lil Uzi Vert
songs.title: New Patek

description.plain:
“New Patek” is a promotional single for Lil Uzi Vert’s March 2020 album, Eternal Atake.

On the song, Uzi references the luxury watch brand Patek Phillipe while bragging about his sexual encounters and accumulated wealth. He also references pop-culture icons like Naruto, Transformers, and Rey Mysterio.

The instrumental is built around a sample of the title track from the Death Parade anime series.

The song was first previewed on Instagram in June 2018, and quickly went viral. During his performance at Lollapalooza 2018, Uzi revealed the song’s title to be “5 Min,” a reference to the song’s run-time of 5:43. However, based on lyrics from the snippet, fans labeled the song as “(New) Patek,” which ultimately became the official song title.

The single artwork is a screenshot from the snippet video in which Uzi was dancing to the song. The glowing hand and the keyhole are a continuation of the Heaven’s Gate cult references present in the album artworks.

songs.full_title: You Was Right by Lil Uzi Vert
songs.title: You Was Right

description.plain:
One of two Metro Boomin produced songs on the Lil Uzi Vert Vs. The World mixtape, Lil Uzi addresses relationship issues and unfaithfulness on “You Was Right.”

Future’s favorite producer provides a signature club-ready beat with an introspective tinge for Uzi’s regretful, yet ratchet, lyrics.

On March 2, 2017 “You Was Right” was certified  platinum, marking Uzi’s first ever platinum single.

songs.full_title: Money Longer by Lil Uzi Vert
songs.title: Money Longer

description.plain:
On “Money Longer,” Lil Uzi Vert contemplates how life has changed since he became famous. The song was first released a track on Uzi’s Soundcloud—a major promo tool for this North Philly rapper.  Now that he’s signed to Atlantic Records, Uzi is turning underground buzz into real money.

Lil Uzi Vert included “Money Longer” on Lil Uzi Vert Vs. The World, a nine-song mixtape released on May 27, 2016,

“Money Longer” was produced by Philly raised Maaly Raw and Atlanta legend DJ Cannon. DJ Cannon first heard Uzi on the radio while driving through Philly.

Uzi told Vibe:

He called my phone. He followed me on Twitter. Shout out to Philly, for real.

songs.full_title: Myron by Lil Uzi Vert
songs.title: Myron

description.plain:
“Myron” starts off Lil Uzi Vert’s LUV Vs. The World 2, the deluxe edition of his second studio album, Eternal Atake.

Originally referred to as “Like Me” by producer Supah Mario before its release, the track was first previewed on Uzi’s Instagram on September 22, 2018. On November 28, Uzi previewed an extended snippet of the song in an Instagram live video.  Finally, on March 6, 2020, Uzi confirmed the track’s title to be “Myron,” along with implying its inclusion on the deluxe edition of Eternal Atake. The next day, Uzi teased two new  snippets from “Myron,” building up the hype for the track even further.

A large portion of the second verse differs from what was heard in previews of the song. This new verse is believed to have been re-recorded and switched out the week Eternal Atake dropped.

songs.full_title: P2 by Lil Uzi Vert
songs.title: P2

description.plain:
“P2”—initialism for Part 2—serves as the sequel to Lil Uzi Vert’s seven-time platinum-selling February 2017 single, “XO TOUR Llif3.” Over yet another TM88-produced instrumental, Uzi interpolates, replicates the flow of, and even samples the original song. The Philadelphia rapper also continues to deal with topics such as his relationship issues with ex-girlfriend, Brittany Byrd and substance abuse.

It’s noteworthy that “P2” and “XO TOUR Llif3” both stand as the sixteenth and closing tracks on their respective projects—“Futsal Shuffle 2020” and “That Way” both being bonus tracks.

“P2” was first teased by Uzi in early February 2020, when he revealed the existence of the song and previewed part of the chorus on Twitter.

songs.title: 20 Min

description.plain:
“20 Min” is the last track of Luv Is Rage 2 (Deluxe). Here Uzi describes the first time he met his ex-girlfriend, Brittany Byrd. This song also talks about other women that have approached Uzi in his music career.

“20 Min” was a much awaited song by fans once Lil Uzi previewed a 30 second snippet of it. Fans could hear the last line of the pre-chorus all the way to the line “But I treat it like my city show.”

description.plain:
This song is dedicated to Lil Uzi Vert’s girlfriend Brittany. He sings about her ex-boyfriend Austin and how he took Brittany from him. The title of the song refers to the saying “Mind your Ps and Qs,” AKA mind your manners.

Uzi commented on his relationship with Brittany during an interview with Nardwuar:

https://youtu.be/_8hxi2UzI9I?t=225

Uzi and producer Don Cannon teased this song to fans through snippets that were posted on Snapchat & Twitter.

songs.full_title: Futsal Shuffle 2020 by Lil Uzi Vert
songs.title: Futsal Shuffle 2020

description.plain:
Lil Uzi Vert switches it up on “Futsal Shuffle 2020,” the first official single for his second studio album Eternal Atake, following September 2018 promotional single “New Patek” and April 2019 promotional singles “Sanguine Paradise” and “That’s a Rack.” The track is the first of two bonus tracks on his 2020 album Eternal Atake.

On November 30, 2019, Lil Uzi Vert announced on Twitter that a “dance record” titled “Futsal” would be the album’s lead single. Uzi would subsequently preview the song and the choreography to his “Futsal Shuffle” dance in a separate tweet.

On December 7, 2019, Uzi teased the track again via Twitter, where he revealed that the track was “coming in days.” Five days later, on December 12, 2019, he confirmed the track’s imminent release on December 13 via Twitter:

FUTSAL SHUFFLE TONIGHT !!!!

The track leaked a few hours before it was officially released as a result of Uzi sending it to many of his friends.

The original instrumental and melody was made by Loesoe and Mayyzo and was an instrumental titled “Lover.”

On January 6, 2020, Lil Uzi Vert released accompanying visuals, after teasing it via Twitter. The music video features Lil Uzi and many other people doing the “Futsal Shuffle” dance in different locations.

songs.full_title: Bean (Kobe) by Lil Uzi Vert (Ft. Chief Keef)
songs.title: Bean (Kobe)

description.plain:
“Bean (Kobe)” (originally titled “Jellybean”) is a track named after the middle name of legendary NBA player Kobe Bean Bryant, who is referenced in the song, and the nickname of his father, former professional basketball player Joe “Jellybean” Bryant, from which Kobe’s middle name originates.

The track was recorded on September 19, 2017, marking one of the first known collaborations between Lil Uzi Vert and Chicago rapper Chief Keef. It was first previewed on the same day in an Instagram story video by Keef. It was later previewed in an Instagram live video by Uzi. Originally thought to be titled “Kobe Rollie” by fans, the track was one of the most highly-anticipated Uzi songs for over two years, with many expecting it to land on Uzi’s then-upcoming Eternal Atake album.

Many fans were upset after it was absent from the final Eternal Atake track list once Uzi announced the listing on March 5, 2020. To the surprise of many fans, the next day, after the standard version of album was released and the deluxe version of Eternal Atake was announced, Uzi teased that the song would finally release on the deluxe in a tweet announcing the song:

Jellybean ( Kobe) ft @ChiefKeef
 🔥 🌟👽

After fans' complaints about the track’s original album mix, Uzi’s go-to engineer, Kesha Lee, previewed an updated mix on her Instagram Story on March 14, 2020. The original album mix is scheduled to be replaced with her mix.

description.plain:
Uzi enlists Nicki Minaj for the remix of “The Way Life Goes.” Uzi keeps his original verses while Nicki adds an additional verse about her elite rap status.

The collaboration first came into works on August 29, 2017, four days after the release of Uzi’s debut album, Luv Is Rage 2. Nicki asked him via Instagram to send her “The Way Life Goes” beat so that she could make a remix to it.

It was apparently due for an earlier release but was delayed due to unknown reasons.

songs.full_title: Sanguine Paradise by Lil Uzi Vert
songs.title: Sanguine Paradise

description.plain:
On “Sanguine Paradise,” Lil Uzi Vert brags about his money, cars, and diamonds, among other various luxuries. The track is one of two promotional singles released for Uzi’s forthcoming album, Eternal Atake, that were released on April 9, 2019.

The song’s instrumental is the work of Philadelphia-based producers Oogie Mane and Brandon Finessin, both of whom are members of the Working on Dying collective. It is built around a sample of Mykko Montana’s 2012 track “Do It,” which would cause a delay in the song’s release due to clearance complications.

“Sanguine Paradise” was originally previewed on December 8, 2018, when Uzi used it as the opening track for his Lil Uzi Vert + Friends concert held in Philadelphia, PA, at the Wells Fargo Center.

The song was leaked online on March 31, 2019, under the fan-made title “Money Keep Coming,” a day prior to the leak of “That’s a Rack.” The leaking of both songs prompted Uzi to respond in a photo posted to his Instagram story, in which he wrote:

Everytime something leak you know everything takes longer ….so have fun

songs.full_title: 7AM by Lil Uzi Vert
songs.title: 7AM

description.plain:
Originally titled “7AM (VLONE LIFESTYLE),” this song was renamed “7AM” for the streming version of Luv is Rage—VLONE is A$AP Rocky and A$AP Bari’s start-up cult fashion line, which Lil Uzi’s girlfriend, Brittany, can be seen wearing in the cover art.



Uzi’s frequent collaborator Playboi Carti also supported VLONE in his song, “VLONE Thug.”

Parts of this song mimic the melody, cadence and theme of Speaker Knockerz' “Annoying.”

songs.full_title: That Way by Lil Uzi Vert
songs.title: That Way

description.plain:
“That Way” is Lil Uzi Vert’s first single of the decade, and the second single off his highly anticipated album Eternal Atake, that is included on the album as a bonus track.

The track’s title comes from the song’s chorus, which interpolates the Backstreet Boys‘ popular April 1999 single “I Want It That Way.”

The track came as a surprise to fans, dropping with only promotion from Roc Nation. The track was previously previewed as a snippet planning to be sold on February 29, 2020. As a result in fear of the track being leaked, it was officially released the next day.

songs.full_title: Baby Pluto by Lil Uzi Vert
songs.title: Baby Pluto

description.plain:
Dubbed “the best song” made by Baby Pluto since Lil Uzi Vert introduced his alter ego, “Baby Pluto” serves as the introduction to Uzi’s long-awaited sophomore studio album, Eternal Atake. The track is also the opener to the “Baby Pluto” third of Eternal Atake.

The aggressive banger energetically kicks off the project with a triumphant vibe, with Uzi rapping a monotone manner instead using his traditional melodic vocals. Uzi is very braggadocios on the song, flexing his sexual prowess and materialistic wealth all over the track while reasserting his position on top of the game.

The instrumental is based on that of Uzi’s unreleased 2017 throwaway “Fast as You Can” produced by Ike Beatz.

songs.full_title: Neon Guts by Lil Uzi Vert (Ft. Pharrell Williams)
songs.title: Neon Guts

description.plain:
Uzi and Pharrell collaborate to create an ode to their colorful and successful life. Ripe with references to happiness and wealth, Uzi and P bounce off of each other in this gleefully produced track; a nice break from some of the more emotional tracks of Luv Is Rage 2.

The song is also produced by Pharrell, and features his signature “four-count” intro.

songs.full_title: Do What I Want by Lil Uzi Vert
songs.title: Do What I Want

description.plain:
While we’re awaiting Uzi’s anticipated project Luv Is Rage 2 Lil Uzi Vert drops a new music video taking a trip to islands of Hawaii to chill in his latest music video off The Perfect LUV Tape. The video features Uzi chilling with his homies and riding dirt bikes and ATV’s around, sticking true to his hometown roots in Philly. The music video has a bit of trippy, psychedelic theme once again implying Lil Uzi is in his own universe. following his last few trippy music videos “Money Longer” and “You Was Right”.

The music video embodies “Do What I Want” lifestyle and shows Lil Uzi enjoying the fruits of his labor celebrating on vacation in Hawaii.



The music video dropped on April 27, 2017.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zqflC-as2Qo

This song was also played in the commercial for Jordan Westbrook 0.2.

https://youtu.be/k8Gsn4hWRNA

songs.title: Dark Queen

description.plain: On “Dark Queen”, Uzi shines a light on his relationship with his mother detailing his understanding of his mothers constant worry on Uzi’s condition, safety and well-being. Uzi acknowledges these worries while also admitting that he too shares her fears, however he firmly states that he was brought up to do what we know he does best.

songs.full_title: Lo Mein by Lil Uzi Vert
songs.title: Lo Mein

description.plain:
The second song on Lil Uzi Vert’s sophomore album Eternal Atake, “Lo Mein” sees Uzi effortlessly riding the beat, rapping in his typical braggadocious style. Uzi details a variety of familiar topics including fashion, jewelry, gun violence, and women. The song’s title is a reference to the Chinese noodle dish Lo Mein which Uzi uses to metaphorically compare chopsticks (which are used to consume Lo Mein) to a firearm.

“Lo Mein” features production from Brandon Finessin and Bugz Ronin. Brandon has worked extensively with Uzi, co-producing hits such as “Sanguine Paradise” and “Futsal Shuffle 2020”.

 Similarly, Bugz has produced 5 songs on Eternal Atake as well as producing for Uzi’s collaborators such as Chief Keef and Yung Bans.

songs.full_title: That’s a Rack by Lil Uzi Vert
songs.title: That’s a Rack

description.plain:
“That’s a Rack” is one of two promotional singles for Lil Uzi Vert’s forthcoming album, Eternal Atake, that were released on April 9, 2019. The song’s instrumental is the work of DJ Bangout and Uzi’s frequent collaborator Oogie Mane. It samples “nm_rabbit_2_140.wav,” a loop from Nick Mira’s The People’s Pack loop kit.

This song was originally previewed for less than a minute by Uzi during his set at Power 99’s Powerhouse event held in Philadelphia, PA, on October 26, 2018. He would preview the song once again at Rolling Loud Festival on December 16, 2018.

“That’s a Rack” was leaked online on April 1, 2019, just a day after the leak of “Sanguine Paradise.” The leaking of both songs prompted Uzi to respond in a photo posted to his Instagram story, in which he wrote:

Everytime something leak you know everything takes longer ….so have fun

songs.full_title: Free Uzi by Lil Uzi Vert
songs.title: Free Uzi

description.plain:
“Free Uzi” is Lil Uzi Vert’s first release since his September 2018 single “New Patek.” The instrumental, produced by DJ L Beats, was originally used in G Herbo’s 2012 single “Gangway.”

The song’s title is in correlation to Uzi’s public struggles with Don Cannon and DJ Drama’s record label, Generation Now, to which he signed to in 2015. Fans would persistently beg both Cannon and Drama to “free Uzi” for months, calling for the release of his forthcoming second studio album, Eternal Atake.

Due to the fact that Atlantic Records nor Generation Now authorized the song’s release, Uzi uploaded “Free Uzi” to streaming services himself through DistroKid. As a result of this, the first service to release the song was TIDAL, which many fans assumed was in connection to his recent management deal with JAY-Z’s entertainment company, Roc Nation. Throughout the day, the song was released on all remaining streaming platforms, followed by its accompanying music video directed by Qasquiat. The song, however, would be subsequently removed from all streaming platforms a day after its release, presumably by Uzi’s label.

“Free Uzi” was first previewed by Uzi in a video posted to his Instagram story on March 25, 2019. In the video, he can be seen in Roc Nation Studios, recording ad-libs over the song that would release three days later.

description.plain:
The fifth track, “SideLine Watching (Hold Up)” on The Perfect Luv Tape is a song mainly centered around Uzi flexing his money and his new girls to his haters and to his ex-girl Brittany. Brittany and Uzi recently went through a break up, and on this song he tries to point out how he doesn’t need her ‘cause his new girl’s got what he needs.

A month before this track was posted, Uzi tweeted out that him and Britney were through.

songs.full_title: 444+222 by Lil Uzi Vert

description.plain:
444 is a reference to JAY-Z and his 13th album 4:44. JAY-Z is namechecked in the song.

The sum of 444 and 222 is 666, or the Biblical “Number of the Beast,” commonly associated with Satan. In 2017, a theory that Uzi was associated with Satan gained traction online, citing evidence such as the similarity between “Lucifer” and “Lil Uzi Vert.” Uzi also wears an inverted cross, or the Cross of Saint Peter, as part of a necklace. Even though the symbol has its roots as a Christian symbol, it is also used to express anti-Christian sentiment and is popular in punk rock, a genre that Uzi draws inspiration from.



This song title, as well as some of the iconography from LUV is Rage 2 depicting Uzi with wings and horns, shows Uzi acknowledging or even embracing the theory.

songs.full_title: Silly Watch by Lil Uzi Vert
songs.title: Silly Watch

description.plain:
“Silly Watch” is yet another song focused on watches by Lil Uzi Vert. The track features Uzi in a similar, braggadocios mood to much of the first third of the album, or the “Baby Pluto” portion of the album. He raps in a cutthroat manner over a dark beat about his material wealth and sexual prowess with women.

“Silly Watch” was teased countless times before its release on Eternal Atake. The track, prior to its release on the album, was known to fans as “40 Glock.” However, producer Supah Mario tweeted in a now-deleted tweet that “40 Glock doesn’t exist,” leading fans to discover that the track was actually called “Silly Watch” once Eternal Atake’s track listing was released on March 5, 2020.

songs.full_title: LUV SCARS K.o 1600 by Lil Uzi Vert
songs.title: LUV SCARS K.o 1600

description.plain:
Lil Uzi Vert reminisces his young life on 1600 Block in his home town of Philadelphia. He explores issues of distrust among those closest to him and mentions spells of disloyalty that have caused him to turn cold towards so called friends. Uzi also pays homage to his close friends Chico and Ninety who were killed in his neighborhood, expressing his sadness for his fallen brothers.

The song was released while he was on the European leg of The Weeknd’s Starboy: Legend of the Fall 2017 world tour. He released this song along with three others as a part of an EP titled Luv Is Rage 1.5.

songs.full_title: Zoom by Lil Uzi Vert
songs.title: Zoom

description.plain:
“Zoom” was originally previewed in a since-deleted Instagram post made by Lil Uzi Vert nearly a month after the release of his debut studio album Luv is Rage 2, which featured the caption:

Just a Vibe💨 ….👨🏾‍🎤vs🌎2® ?🙄

This caption would spark the assumption that the song would land on a forthcoming, as-of-yet unreleased, sequel to his Lil Uzi Vert Vs. The World mixtape from 2016.

In July 2019, FaZe Clan member Nordan, better known as FaZe Rain, took to Snapchat and played part of the song. He later joked about dropping it, however, he then went back on it, saying he “didn’t want to do Uzi like that.” Despite this, the song later leaked externally on August 10, 2019. It appears quite unfinished, featuring mostly the same lyrics looping throughout the track.

songs.full_title: Prices by Lil Uzi Vert
songs.title: Prices

description.plain:
“Prices”  features Uzi in a very braggadocios manner, claiming his money, fame, and overall “price” are going up.

The track was first teased by producer Brandon Finessin’s on his Instagram Live video on March 2, 2020. Later, fans got confirmation that the track would appear on Eternal Atake after a snippet of its instrumental was played in the album’s short film Baby Pluto.

The track samples the instrumental from the second half of Travis Scott’s September 2016 track “way back,” which was produced by Cashmere Cat.

songs.full_title: Two® by Lil Uzi Vert
songs.title: Two®

description.plain: “Two®” marks Lil Uzi Vert’s first song of his album Luv Is Rage 2, and is named specifically to show Uzi’s transition from his 2015 album Luv Is Rage. On the track he discusses the fact that he now has money and power in the music industry. The song explains how “SoundCloud rappers” are biting his style and stealing his cadence to attempt to ride the wave for fame. The song also talks about how people should be thanking him for innovating the hip-hop industry because he feels like a lot of people wouldn’t be popping right now if it wasn’t for him and his crazy style.

Lil Uzi Vert talks about having sexual intercourse with a girl while toting major car brands and flexing his money in the process

songs.full_title: Sasuke by Lil Uzi Vert
songs.title: Sasuke

description.plain:
“Sasuke” is the first single by Lil Uzi Vert following his March 2020 album, Eternal Atake, and its deluxe edition, Lil Uzi Vert vs. The World 2. The title is an ode to Sasuke Uchiha, a character in Naruto, the anime and manga series. Uzi has had a continued and documented infatuation with anime.

On the song, Uzi raps about his usual topics of sex, weapons, and wealth, but he also makes references to Sasuke and the Naruto series.

During the week leading up to the single’s release, Uzi hinted at the song’s title with a series of tweets referencing “Sasuke” as his new alter-ego, following his “Orenji” and “Baby Pluto” monikers from earlier in 2020. “Sasuke” is Uzi’s second Naruto-influenced alter-ego, as “Orenji” was based upon Pain, a villain in the series.

The single also arrives amidst a dispute between Uzi and his former close collaborator, Playboi Carti. On March 19, 2020, Uzi tweeted that he would drop more music as soon as an unnamed individual dropped music of their own, which many assumed was a subtle shot at Carti.

After Carti released his single, “@ MEH,” on April 16, Uzi began to promote his own music in correlation with everything that Carti posted on social media. Uzi announced this single about four hours before its release by unveiling its artwork. Uzi notably takes from Carti’s style in this track, from the use of Carti’s adlibs to his mimicking of Carti’s “baby voice.”

Uzi and Carti ultimately squashed their beef on April 25, hours after this track was released.

songs.full_title: Homecoming by Lil Uzi Vert
songs.title: Homecoming

description.plain:
“Homecoming” (originally titled “Philly Jawn”) is the last track in the “Baby Pluto” segment of Eternal Atake, finishing off the cutthroat, aggressive segment of rap seen on the record.

Over a very bass-heavy beat scarce of instruments, Uzi raps ruthlessly about topics typical to his rap such as material wealth in the form of jewelry and cars as well as a female named Nicki who is referenced all over the track.

songs.full_title: Super Saiyan by Lil Uzi Vert
songs.title: Super Saiyan

description.plain:
Super Saiyan Trunks (simply titled “Super Saiyan” on his Luv Is Rage mixtape) is one of Uzi’s first breakthrough hits. It’s produced by Slade Da Monsta.

The name of this song comes from Uzi’s love of the popular animated series Dragon Ball Z, where powerful members of Saiyan race (including Trunks, one of the most powerful Saiyans in the world) can transform and go [Super Saiyan]

Additionally, Lil Uzi was known for having purple hair at the time, like Trunks in DBZ before going super saiyan.

songs.full_title: I'm Sorry by Lil Uzi Vert
songs.title: I’m Sorry

description.plain:
This track ends the section of “Baby Pluto” songs and begins the “Renji” section of the album, one of Uzi’s personalities who he has described as being the more “sweet” and “nice” side of his personality.

Since Renji is a reflection of Uzi’s softer side, the track is an apology to a past lover with whom Uzi’s relationship went sour. The line “that’s why you can’t fuck with fans” is a clear sign that this song is about Brittany Byrd, one of Uzi’s ex-girlfriends. He has discussed their relationship in many songs, including “20 Min” from Luv is Rage 2, where he tells the story of him meeting her in the crowd at one of his shows. The cover art of the first Luv Is Rage album is also a depiction of this happening.

This song is an apology to Brittany, apologizing for potentially being misleading and letting his fame affect their relationship together.

The Renji section of the album ends with “Prices,” with “Urgency” being the first song off of the album’s Uzi section. Uzi confirmed this on Twitter the day of the album’s release.

songs.full_title: Lotus by Lil Uzi Vert
songs.title: Lotus

description.plain:
“Lotus” is the second track on Lil Uzi Vert vs. the World 2, which also serves as the deluxe version of Lil Uzi Vert’s second studio album, Eternal Atake.

The track was previewed in 2018 by Uzi on an Instagram live video on Young Thug’s Instagram account.

On March 7, 2020, Uzi tweeted lyrics from the pre-chorus of “Lotus”:

I pull up in a lamb this not a lotussssssssss …..

Later that day, he further confirmed the track would appear on the deluxe version of the record with another tweet:

Myron ….lotus …
jellybean is  (Kobe Rollie) … what else

songs.full_title: How to Talk by Lil Uzi Vert
songs.title: How to Talk

description.plain:
On “How to Talk,” Philadelphia rapper Lil Uzi Vert implores for his significant other to treat him with respect and be encouraging to him. The track features an aggressive intro from DreamDoll who accuses Uzi of deception, which serves as the basis behind the track.

This track marks the first collaboration between the two rappers.

songs.full_title: Moon Relate by Lil Uzi Vert
songs.title: Moon Relate

description.plain:
On “Moon Relate” (originally titled “Me and The Moon Relate”), Lil Uzi Vert uses the moon as a metaphor for the effects of drugs and expresses his frequently-mentioned claim of not being from Earth.

The original track was recorded in 2017 during production of Uzi’s debut studio album, Luv Is Rage 2, and was thrown away from the project. It was previewed online in June 2017 and September 2017. It began to circulate in 2019 but was not leaked. It was confirmed to be on the deluxe version of Uzi’s 2020 sophomore studio album, Eternal Atake, on March 8, 2020, by Uzi on Twitter after fans requested its release on Twitter:
https://twitter.com/LILUZIVERT/status/1236596690087489536

The album version was confirmed to be a rerecorded version after it was previewed by Uzi on Twitter on March 8, 2020:
https://twitter.com/LILUZIVERT/status/1236783077659156480

The original 2017 version of the track was leaked ten hours before the album version’s release. The album version features rawer vocals and added synthesizers to the instrumental.

songs.title: Of Course

description.plain:
“Of Course” is a highly anticipated song recorded for Lil Uzi Vert’s sophomore studio album, Eternal Atake.

The song was periodically previewed by many, even by Uzi himself during the Endless Summer Tour and on Instagram Live. It would eventually leak online on October 13, 2018, prompting a response from Don Cannon on Instagram:



Copyright strikes were later issued to uploads of the song on media sharing sites. The copyright message listed the song’s title as “Of Course Intro,” indicating that it might have been the intro on an early version of Eternal Atake.
